prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Charmandaris et al. (2000) detected CO(1-0) and CO(2-1) at single positions with the SEST telescope toward the S1 and S2 shells with a strength of 0.03K in their ~40" beam, or 0.5\,Jy. They derived a molecular mass in the two shells of a few times 10^7 M_sun. With ALMA, we like to obtain a rms of 15 mJy to map the detected objects with at least a signal-to-noise ratio of 30, and to be able to detect gas that is about an order of magnitude weaker. Typical giant molecular clouds are of order 40 pc. To match this scale, we ask for a resolution of ~2".
The observations are all mosaics and we broke them up into different science goals, one for each region. We had to increase the pointing distance to 0.7 times the primary beam to be able to map all regions within the total 150 pointing limit of Cycle 2. Not ideal, but the large number antennas offered for ALMA will provide an adequate uv-coverage, despite sub-Nyquist sampling. The signal-to-noise that we want to achieve will be high enough to account for a non-uniform noise distribution that may be derived from this procedure.
ALMA is very sensitive and the entire 148 pointings can be observed with a total of only ~4h to an unprecedented sensitivity.
As a secondary goal, we also like to observe the CN(1-0) line as it falls into the tuning range of the CO setup. CN is a photo-dominated region tracer that will provide us insight in the chemistry in these extraordinary regions, if detected. To complete the setup, we also include two continuum frequencies. The jets of Cen A are not very bright at 115 GHz, but we nevertheless will be able to detect the continuum at the same time as the line emission for a direct comparison of their interactions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Despite theories that predict that a radio jet quenches star formation in galaxies, the most nearby radio galaxy Centaurus A shows a wealth of star formation activity that is apparently triggered by the central jet. The star forming regions are characterized by Halpha and far-ultraviolet emission, as well as HI and dust, aligned with optical shells. CO has only been searched for with SEST and has been weakly detected. We propose to map regions along the radio jet of Centaurus A to determine the molecular content and distribution. A comparison with the star formation tracers will allow us to derive the position of the jet-induced star formation on the Kennicutt-Schmidt law. Deviations will provide insight on the shock properties of the gas. We will also be able to derive the star formation efficiency of this rather unusual star formation mechanism that, however, might play a vital role in galaxy feedback mechanisms.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
